content.description:
Second pitch - thin. Fun climbing. Above Bunny Slope if memory serves.  

  Jeremy Haas told me about this "project" in 2011 while I was living in New Paltz and making frequent trips to the Dacks. He said that it had been toproped clean, but never led; and originally graded 5.13b. I felt that it was probably a bit easier, but still contained some pretty tenuous climbing. I hope the person who was working on it got back to it: we kept the original name!
content.protection: Gear for P1 as per Bunny Slope

content.description: Easier terrain moves into a harder bulge move, before quickly gaining the anchors on a comfortable ledge.
content.location: This is the second bolt line you will encounter, at the far left end of the cliff.

content.description: Follow bolts up a steep face to a strenuous move left and up to a stance.  Up the slab and overhanging corner past a technical crux to a stance.  Easier fun climbing leads to a bolted anchor.    Jeremy said that Endless Journey is his favorite route at Potash, but this is mine.  Superb.
content.protection: Eight bolts to a bolted anchor.
content.location: On the right side of the main cliff, where the base of the cliff starts to slope upwards. In-between the obvious finger crack through the roof (Fear of a Flat Planet) and the bolted arete at the right end of the cliff (Black Dog).

content.description: Perhaps a bit stout in the grade, and reminiscent of Ravenous at Eagle Falls-the stemming in the corner is technical and thrilling!The beginning is shared with El Regalo: Climb up onto the left rising ramp, clip the humongous piton thing and climb onto the big boulder. Make an awkward move to gain a small corner and climb up to the cedar tree.Instead of going left of the cedar tree (as for El Regalo), go to the right of it and up to a hand traverse ledge. Work right past two bolts and under the big hanging arete. Make a couple of powerful moves over a bulge with a bolt at your face (crux) to gain the corner above. Stem, palm, crimp, and sidepull your way up past a flake, a ceiling, and some easier jugs to a fixed anchor.
content.protection: quick draws, maybe an alpine draw. fixed anchor.
content.location: Same as El Regalo: below a large left rising ramp with a large boulder on it. A new bolt has been added to facilitate the start of several routes here-it makes gaining the ledge safe and easy.

content.description: The beginning of this excellent route involves establishing a belay at the top of a ramp, clipping a bong (for your belayer's sake), and then trending up and right to get to the first bolt.  From there, the fun starts, with the option of pulling on a small tree (which I most certainly did), or traversing around it.  After the tree, the moves get harder, with a nice no-hands rest on a ledge about two thirds of the way up.  The trick is convincing yourself to step back off the ledge onto the crimpy headwall to finish it out.
content.location: This route starts at the top of a left-trending ramp, in the first section of lighter-colored rock.  It runs up an obvious orangish face with a tree sticking out of it.

content.description: Easy terrain leads to the obvious, 15-foot section of splitter finger-crack in a dihedral.
content.protection: Small to medium gear.  Fixed anchors at the top.
content.location: Use this route to locate others on the cliff, as it is the most obvious centerpiece crack in the main section of cliff.  When standing on the large boulders at the main cliff area (to the right of El Regalo), you can't miss it.

content.description: Layback flake, trending left to a mantle ledge, followed by a clean crack to the anchors.  Great movement, with bomber placements.
content.location: This climb shares anchors with Double Diamonds (which is just to the left).  It follows the easier flake up and leftward to the chains.

content.description: Start in the corner, moving onto the right wall at some obvious holds. Climb the technical and continuous arete to a stance under an overhang. Move a little right, pull the overhang (10a), and climb a short slab to a fixed anchor.Â
content.protection: 5 bolts to a 2 bolt anchor with rings.It may be a good idea to stick clip the first bolt as the landing is not ideal if you blow the clip.
content.location: At the right end of the main cliff at Potash, look for an obvious bolted arete.

content.description: Good warm-up climb with a fun series of blocks and stemming.
content.location: This is the first (leftmost) bolt line you will encounter.  It is in the treed section, before you move out onto the large boulders at the main cliff area.

content.description:
This relatively small cliff offers a variety of good quality climbing, with both sport and trad routes.  It is mostly south-facing, so gets daytime sun.  However, there is plenty of tree shade and decent belay areas. 

  The rock is some variety of granite, with positive holds or cracks.
